contentSection.headline: Master Employment Law Fundamentals That Protect Your Organization
contentSection.description: HR Law Fundamentals is 2 intensive days where you'll master discrimination law, ADA/FMLA compliance, wage-hour requirements, and hiring/termination risk—working through real workplace scenarios with practicing employment attorneys, not theoretical lectures.
benefits: Complete legal foundation – Discrimination defense, ADA/FMLA accommodations, wage-hour compliance, hiring risk, termination law, performance management, and HR investigations
Real-world application – Work through discrimination claims, accommodation requests, termination decisions, and the legal challenges you'll face Monday morning
Expert attorney instruction – Learn from practicing employment attorneys who handle these cases and defend employers every day
Professional certification – Earn your certificate plus 13 SHRM/HRCI/CLE continuing education credits

header.title: What You'll Master in 2 Days
header.description: A complete employment law foundation covering discrimination defense, ADA/FMLA compliance, wage-hour law, hiring and selection, performance management, termination risk, workplace safety, and HR investigations.

blocks.label: Full Program
blocks.title: HR Law Fundamentals
blocks.description: Master the legal foundation every HR professional needs to protect their organization.

competencyGroups.title: The New Landscape of Workplace Discrimination (2026)
competencyGroups.description: What's changing in discrimination law and how to adapt policies, training, and investigations.

skills.title: Expansion of protected characteristics under state law
skills.description: Update policies and training to comply with expanding protected classes including gender identity, hairstyles/hygiene, and reproductive decisions.

skills.title: Retaliation remains #1 EEOC claim
skills.description: Structure responses so protected activity doesn't convert routine actions into retaliation claims.

skills.title: Religious accommodation conflicts (post-Groff)
skills.description: Apply post-Groff standards to balance sincere beliefs with operational and coworker impacts.

skills.title: Harassment outside the four walls
skills.description: Address remote misconduct, chat/messaging platforms, and bystander liability with clear rules and prompt action.

skills.title: Reverse discrimination and post-DEI backlash claims
skills.description: Spot and mitigate risks as DEI programs face reverse-bias and retaliation allegations.

competencyGroups.title: ADA, FMLA & Accommodation in a Hybrid Workplace
competencyGroups.description: Define essential functions, manage mental health accommodations, and avoid overlap traps in hybrid settings.

skills.title: Documenting the interactive process
skills.description: Create a contemporaneous record that shows good-faith exploration of accommodation options.

skills.title: Determining essential job functions when hybrid/remote is feasible
skills.description: Define essential duties defensibly when remote and hybrid options exist.

skills.title: Mental health accommodations and the new expectation of flexibility
skills.description: Navigate mental health requests while maintaining performance and fairness.

skills.title: When performance issues are really medical/legal issues
skills.description: Differentiate conduct from condition to choose coaching, discipline, or accommodation.

skills.title: Overlap traps: FMLA + ADA + workers' comp + pregnancy accommodation
skills.description: Coordinate leave and accommodation laws to avoid conflicts and double liability.

competencyGroups.title: Hiring & Selection Compliance (Modern Risk Areas)
competencyGroups.description: Compliant recruiting in 2026—from pay transparency to AI screening risks.

skills.title: Pay transparency laws and salary band posting requirements
skills.description: Meet posting rules while preserving market competitiveness and internal equity.

skills.title: Salary history bans (still expanding state by state)
skills.description: Remove salary-history bias from hiring and compensation decisions.

skills.title: Negligent hiring & social media screening pitfalls
skills.description: Use verifiable criteria and documented sources; avoid protected-class data.

skills.title: Inclusive interviewing without increasing risk
skills.description: Ask job-related, validated questions that minimize discrimination risk.

skills.title: AI/algorithmic recruiting laws (CO, NY, CA, IL emerging models)
skills.description: Audit automated tools for bias, disclosures, and candidate opt-outs.

competencyGroups.title: Wage & Hour Law in 2026
competencyGroups.description: Stop off-the-clock risk, handle breaks and commutes, and avoid misclassification crackdowns.

skills.title: Remote/off-the-clock time: when quick emails become unpaid work
skills.description: Set boundaries and capture all hours for non-exempt remote work.

skills.title: Travel time & hybrid commutes — what must be paid?
skills.description: Apply federal and state rules to travel, home office trips, and training.

skills.title: Pay transparency intersects with wage claims
skills.description: Align postings, pay practices, and records to withstand claims.

skills.title: Meal/rest break liability under remote tracking
skills.description: Ensure compliant break tracking and off-duty controls for remote staff.

skills.title: Misclassification crackdowns (independent contractor & salaried/exempt)
skills.description: Reassess roles and duties before audits target grey areas.

competencyGroups.title: Managing & Supervising Employees (HR as Risk Gatekeeper)
competencyGroups.description: Tools managers need to document well, coach correctly, and reduce retaliation risk.

skills.title: Coaching vs discipline vs accommodation: knowing which lane you're in
skills.description: Pick the right path early to avoid mixed messages and legal exposure.

skills.title: Documentation as legal shield — what juries look for
skills.description: Write contemporaneous, behavior-based notes that show fairness and consistency.

skills.title: Digital tone, Teams/Slack as evidence
skills.description: Model respectful, concise communication that's safe to print in court.

skills.title: The silent plaintiff file — managers' notebooks and emails as discovery exhibits
skills.description: Assume side notes and chats will be exhibits; keep them professional.

skills.title: Legal do's & don'ts of progressive discipline
skills.description: Follow clear steps, timelines, and expectations without rigid traps.

competencyGroups.title: Performance Management & Evaluations
competencyGroups.description: Write defensible evaluations and plans that hold up in litigation.

skills.title: Why evaluations are Exhibit A in litigation
skills.description: Make ratings match reality; avoid inflated scores that suggest pretext.

skills.title: He was always rated 'exceeds' — until termination = pretext
skills.description: Use trend lines and notes to explain performance changes.

skills.title: Writing defensible comments based on behavior not personality
skills.description: Anchor comments in observable actions, metrics, and impact.

skills.title: Self-appraisals as risk management tool
skills.description: Capture employee input to reduce disputes and surface issues early.

skills.title: Corrective action plans that legally protect the company
skills.description: Include specific behaviors, supports, deadlines, and consequences.

competencyGroups.title: Termination Law & Separation Risk
competencyGroups.description: Assess retaliation, handle references, and use releases appropriately.

skills.title: At-will vs implied contracts (what unintentionally creates one)
skills.description: Avoid language and practices that look like job guarantees.

skills.title: Off-duty conduct & political/social issue firings
skills.description: Balance brand and policy with lawful off-workplace protections.

skills.title: Retaliation analysis before discharge
skills.description: Audit timeline, comparators, and documentation before acting.

skills.title: Requests for references & defamation risk
skills.description: Share neutral facts and required verifications only.

skills.title: Severance/releases — when HR should recommend counsel
skills.description: Use tailored terms and timing to maximize enforceability.

competencyGroups.title: Workplace Safety, Leave Laws & Special Compliance Areas
competencyGroups.description: OSHA 2.0, FMLA documentation, threats, dual-risk areas, and required flags.

skills.title: Psychological safety = OSHA 2.0 (emerging enforcement theory)
skills.description: Address psychosocial hazards with training, reporting, and response plans.

skills.title: FMLA abuse vs legal protected use — documentation rules
skills.description: Tighten certifications, recertifications, and call-in rules lawfully.

skills.title: Workplace threats & duty to act
skills.description: Build multidisciplinary response protocols for credible threats.

skills.title: Workers' comp plus ADA = dual risk area
skills.description: Coordinate restrictions, RTW, and accommodations across programs.

skills.title: WARN, COBRA, ERISA (what HR must flag, even if counsel handles details)
skills.description: Know the triggers and timelines HR must escalate immediately.

competencyGroups.title: HR Investigations (HR Edition, Non-Legal Version)
competencyGroups.description: When to investigate, how to stay neutral, and retaliation-proof the aftermath.

skills.title: When HR must investigate vs when coaching is sufficient
skills.description: Triage complaints quickly to choose the right response path.

skills.title: Neutrality and avoiding confirmation bias
skills.description: Use structured questions and corroboration to keep findings objective.

skills.title: What you can/can't promise about confidentiality
skills.description: Set realistic privacy expectations while protecting the process.

skills.title: Handling reluctant witnesses or anonymous complaints
skills.description: Build participation through safeguards, not pressure.

skills.title: Retaliation-proofing the aftermath
skills.description: Implement follow-ups and guardrails after findings are delivered.

faq.question: What happens after I register?
faq.answer: Within minutes, you'll receive an invoice email. Once payment is processed, you can schedule your complimentary pre-program consultation (10-15 minutes) to discuss your specific HR legal challenges—whether you're dealing with accommodation requests, termination decisions, or compliance issues. Pre-program materials arrive one week before your session starts.

faq.question: What's the difference between in-person and virtual formats?
faq.answer: Both formats feature the same practicing attorney instructors, current legal content, and professional credits. In-person provides face-to-face networking with other HR professionals. Virtual delivers the same live instruction via Zoom with full Q&A capability. Choose the format that fits your schedule—the quality and content remain identical.

faq.question: What continuing education credits will I earn?
faq.answer: The 2-day program provides 13 SHRM/HRCI/CLE credits. Plus, your enrollment includes 12 months of quarterly employment law updates (4 sessions × 1.5 credits each = 6 additional credits), bringing your total to 19 credits.

faq.question: Is this the same as Block I of the Certificate in Strategic HR Leadership?
faq.answer: Yes. HR Law Fundamentals is Block I of the full Certificate in Strategic HR Leadership program. You can take it as a standalone 2-day program, or combine it with Strategic HR Management (Block II) to earn the full certificate and save $575.

faq.question: I already have some HR legal knowledge. Is this too basic for me?
faq.answer: Probably not. Employment law has changed significantly—post-Groff religious accommodation standards, AI hiring regulations in multiple states, expanded protected characteristics, new FMLA/ADA intersection traps, and hybrid workplace compliance issues. Many experienced HR professionals find that what they learned 3-5 years ago no longer reflects current legal standards. This program updates your legal foundation with 2026 realities.

faq.question: How current is the legal content?
faq.answer: Very. The curriculum addresses the latest employment law developments including 2026 pay transparency laws, AI hiring regulations (CO, NY, CA, IL), post-Groff religious accommodation standards, hybrid workplace wage-hour issues, and evolving discrimination law. Our instructors update content based on cases they're currently handling.

faq.question: Does the $1,375 program fee include everything?
faq.answer: Yes. Your enrollment includes all live instruction from practicing employment attorneys, complete program materials, 13 continuing education credits, pre-program consultation, 12 months of quarterly employment law updates (4 sessions, $1,588 value), permanent access to updated resources, and alumni benefits for all future programs. The only additional cost would be travel and lodging if you choose in-person format.

faq.question: Can I apply this toward the full Certificate in Strategic HR Leadership?
faq.answer: Yes. HR Law Fundamentals (Block I) counts toward the full certificate. You can complete Strategic HR Management (Block II) at any future session to earn the complete Certificate in Strategic HR Leadership.
